✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Not too challenging but great topic to learn about.

import itertools

def stereo(pattern, stock, depths):
    result = ''
    for old, new in zip([0] + depths, depths):
        if new > old:
            pattern = pattern[new - old : ]
        elif old > new:
            pattern = list(itertools.islice(stock, old - new)) + pattern
        result += pattern[0]
        pattern = pattern[1 : ] + [pattern[0]]
    return result

input()
pattern = list(input())
input()
stock = list(input())
height, _ = [int(i) for i in input().split()]
for _ in range(height):
    depths = [int(i) for i in input()]
    print(stereo(pattern, itertools.cycle(stock), depths))

So I see an approval with only 2 days left to validate. I think I could attempt this if I were motivated, but it just looks like an arbitrary procedure to me. I really don't get how this is a stereogram. :-\
Like it

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It takes some time to get through, but I really like how simple the solution can be.
i like

I think that the level of difficulty is underestimated because of the complexity of the statement and the presence of special cases (SPOILER ALERT e.g. decreasing both the end and the start of the pattern at the same time if the current position + the change in depth is greater than the length of the pattern)
I also do not have the cultural background necessary to link the introduction paragraph with the challenge and I do not think that people will take the time to check the wikipedia page
These things apart, I enjoyed solving this puzzle
I'm happy to change it to Medium.
You know how to view Magic Eye pictures? Try that with the output. The Lattice and View Fullscreen validators are easiest to see, in my opinion.
If you think it should be easy, please don't approve and instead request the change then approve.

You're right, it should be easy. I wasn't that specific, tho. I just said it wasn't challenging... but that's usually true when you know of better ways to do things. With a solution more like Snoyes, I didn't run into Oddrea's problem. That said, even Oddrea omitted it should probably be easy.

An autostereogram works by tricking your brain into thinking both eyes are focused in the same place, when in reality they are looking at two different copies of a pattern. By making the pattern slightly longer or shorter, you take advantage of your binocular vision to create apparent differences in depth. It's the algorithm described here; they just usually use letters so tiny that they are actually pixels instead of letters.

Oh I didn't realize I'm meant to view the output as a stereogram itself, I thought it was just a bumpmap or color coding or something. I'm trying now but unfortunately I can't see it in the ascii, even after training on stock images to be sure I'm doing it right. In truth there aren't many of those that I'm able to get anyway. And then once the focus is right, there's a question of what the shape even is, because some of them are quite weird. So my question now is, what makes a stereogram easier for viewing (and therefore better, in my opinion)? Why is it that I'm readily able to see so much more detail in some and not in others?

The width of the pattern has to be right. Too wide and you can't "unfocus" your eyes enough to show the same piece of the pattern to each eye; too narrow and you overshoot, looking at the second or third iteration away.

The density of the pattern has to be right. A pattern that is too sparse doesn't give you much information to go on and makes it hard to find the focus.

A depth map that is too deep or too complicated is hard to see too.

The pattern can be generated for either "wide-eyed" viewing (as here) or "cross-eyed". If you view it the wrong way, you end up with an inverted image - like seeing the mold instead of the casting.

Admitedly it's harder to see these ASCII versions, partly because the test cases are limited to 1000 total characters, so you really can't make the depth map wide enough to frame it with a few dozen 0s as I would have liked.

Here's a larger one, generated with the same program:
https://pastebin.com/raw/x8STa2VT
Try zooming out until the whole thing fits on the screen.

Here's the input that produced it:
https://pastebin.com/raw/bXiSXu1q

It's a reduced version of https://i.stack.imgur.com/LzJQx.png

Sweet, I finally saw it! And before looking at the input, the dot in the very middle (which turns out to be depth 5) stood out prominently. But it does look more like hard contours than the geometric figure I'd never have guessed.

Here's the first image I was able to get to pop today. What I see is a hard cut along a kind of circular border, with some detail inside I can't quite make out. When I tried deliberately crossing my eyes, I saw something else, one round figure within another. So I don't think it was an issue of looking at it wrong.
https://i.pinimg.com/originals/5e/b5/f7/5eb5f702972f40770712de1d0d3bd876.jpg

That one looks something like a nautilus, like https://aambpublicoceanservice.blob.core.windows.net/oceanserviceprod/facts/nautilus.jpg

That one is not a "random dot" stereogram; it uses an image as the base pattern instead of a random string of pixels. That makes it a lot easier for your eyes to find the focus.

It was tagged as a snake, but who knows if that's right. I think the reason it was my first success today is that it has a wide margin without any noise. All the detail is in the center, in other words, so my eyes never get drawn to the edges. And furthermore the hard cut along the border of the figure makes the pop extremely obvious when it happens.

I'm thinking, if you could give instruction on padding the images (what would happen if it were surrounded by many more zeroes), then someone who wanted to view it before solving it could do that to make it easier on themselves, limitations be damned. Or better yet, just link to an example like the one you gave me, if that's allowed.

If I have time after solving it, I'm going to experiment with different characters to see if there are combinations that work better than others. As with the color stereograms, the black and white ones that I've been able to see have great contrast across the pattern, such as this one.
https://basik.ru/images/black_and_white_magic_eye/13_magic_eye.gif
I have added some links to an example which is wide enough to see more easily.

Actually I thought it was designed for Clash of Code when I wrote it. Maybe Easy is right for this puzzle without the time constraint
This update also applies to the second part of what I wrote : people may be eager to look for information if they have time
